name: nytimes
text:
The masks muffled the chants this election season. But often, in the campaign's final days, the theme was clear: It's something like survival, getting to 2021 in one piece, individually and collectively.

Here's what @mattfleg and @heislerphoto saw. https://t.co/ALdKDroBzp

name: nytimes
text:
Aside from the date of the election, almost everything is different.

On the campaign trail, on one side, campaign rallies have often been reduced to car-bound honk-fests. On the other, they're at once undimmed and discouraged by public health authorities. https://t.co/ALdKDroBzp https://t.co/agn65fvRMV

name: nytimes
text:
With coronavirus cases rising in the U.S., Europe and many other places across the globe, wearing a mask is more important than ever.

In our animation, we‚Äôll show you how effective a swath of fabric can be at fighting the pandemic. https://t.co/8NuIYjLVTf

name: nytimes
text: Masks come in many styles and materials, but they generally work in the same way, using a system called filtration.‚Ä¶ https://t.co/SyYOHhR7lR

name: nytimes
text:
Masks of all kinds vary in how efficient they are based on their shape and fit.

A good mask will have a large surface area, a tight fit around the edges, and a shape that leaves space around your nostrils and mouth. https://t.co/u2S9PbBIwQ https://t.co/jDfq6UfYI0

name: nytimes
text: When everyone wears a mask, the chance of transmission is reduced even more. Let‚Äôs say the mask you‚Äôre wearing filters half of the particles. Those that escape disperse and are further diluted. The ones that reach someone else‚Äôs mask get filtered again. https://t.co/u2S9PbBIwQ https://t.co/ebSkBZ1ei4

name: nytimes
text:
We also have an augmented reality component that lets you stand in front of the magnified fibers of an N95 respirator and launch particles to learn how the mask fibers capture them.

This link will take you to Instagram (if you‚Äôre on your phone).

https://t.co/EkUO7XbiKo
